div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.
MESOPOTAMIA AND BRITISH
ENGINEERS.

While the Bagdad Railway still linger, on its way eastward, the fertile delta of the Euphrates is being slowly but surely developed by the Daire Sanich of His Imperial Majesty tbe Sultan. Large new-areas are being brought under cultivation, tho riverine trade is increasing rapidly, and tho railway, when it readies its goal, will traverse for the last 200 miles of its route a district where much has been done to repair the neglect of centuries. With the opening up of the country to trade and the incrcaao of cultivation, the demand for mechanical appliances of every description is bound to increase, and from news received from what wo believe to be a well-informed source, we gather that there is already a considerable demand for oil pumps at Basra and Bagdad. Hitherto the general want of technical skill has militated against their introduction. It is all very well to introduce machinery, but what if none of tho purchasers are ablo to instal it or to manage it when installed 1 The answer is simple: tho engineering firms must themselves undertake the instruction of the purchasers. They will have to do, not with stupid barbarians, but with a race that possesses many of the best characteristics of the Egyptian, joined to quicker wit. and greater readiness to accept responsibility. And if British engineering firm, with to share in the profita that will certainly accrue to the engineering trade os a whole from tho opening up of Mesopotamia they must set to work themselves to push their machinery and to instruct their clientele how to moke the most advantageous use of their purchases.

What is required to ensure success is tho dispatch to the spot of a competent and responsible representative of tbe British engineering trade. He should virit Mesopotamia in the winter, make local enquiriea, give reliable technical advice, provide estimates, and receive orders. He should be accompanied by a reliable and tactful fitter, who would stay for at least a year os a trial, and who could bn trusted to put up pumps so that they would work at their maximum efficiency, and repair any machines that get out of order. He should also be prepared to give instructions to persons to bo employed in taking charge of pumps. Let a combination of British firms tako this course, and they will have an excellent chanco of securing this market for British machinery. If they wait, the lapse of every month brings with it a greater risk that French or German firms will enter the field. If the home firms are unwilling to try the experiment arc there no British engineering companies in Egypt with the imagination and vigour to tackle the problem 1 They will have every assistance from H.B.M.'s Consul at Bagdad.

div.head: U.S.A. and the Congo
King Leopold's Clever Move
Deputation to Sir Edward Grey
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)

LONDON. Tuesday, Nov. 20. An Antwerp correspondent says that Kin# Leopold’s concern ion to an American company of the cnltivation right* on a million hectares of Inndin the Congo Fres State, with ten year*’ option of pnrcha.se at half a million, i* consi dered a clever move on the part of the a*tnte monarch, as hy so doing he implicates America in the international sitnation. (Gazette’s Spoclal Sorvlce.) LONDON Wednesday. Nov. 21. Sir El ward Grey, replying to a deputation wh'Hi waited on him in regard to *ho administration of the Congo State, said' that should Belgium fail to take the matter out of the hands of King Leopold, it will became oar dnty to summon R conference r.f the signatory Powers to the Treaty of Berlin, for farther erqniry and common aotion. LONDON November 20. Replying to a representative deputation regarding the Congo Free S'ste. Sir E Grey said that the Be’gian Government had the prior right to intervene. If it did, it would certain’y have to make a complete chance in the regime, ntherwi-e Groat B-itain wonld soand the Powers wi'h a view to a conference. She wonld only take isolated aotion a* a lsst, resonree. (Reuter)

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Quarantine In Turkey. A telegram from Pera states that fhe quarantine restrictions against arrivals from Bey- root have been removed. The Brindisi Mall. The mail from Europe, vi& Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 9 p.m. to-day. American Oil for Egypt. The S.3. Milton, which arrived here on fhe 19th inst., discharged 61,000 cases of refined oil, 11P,0( 0 cans, and 2,000 cases of naphtha Counoll of Ministers. The Council of Ministers will meet at A1 dren. Palace, under the presidency of the Khedive, shortly after his Highnesu’s arrival in Cairo, in order to pas* the budgetary estimates for 1907. Khedlvial Agricultural 8ociety. The Rbedivi’nl Agricultural Society will mept on the 24th inst., nnder the pTe*idency of Prince Hus-ein Pasha Kamel, to discuss the question of\ dredging canals. P.W.D. Contracts. Surety for con tracts for the Ministry of Public Works is henceforth fixed at L. E 400, and not at 10 per cent, of ibe total estimated cost of the undertaking. Presentation of Medal. On Sunday last, tbs medafcfor Long Service an! Good Conduct was presented to Foreman of Works Q lartermaster Sergeant W.E Sann- darn, R.E., on parade after church at RbS el Tin. Tourist Accommodation in Egypt. It has been estimated that the hotels visited by tourists in Egypt at Alexandria (including the Savoy Palace Hotel), Cairo (iuclnding the Hotel Stmiramis). Luxor, and Assouan now accommodate 6,000 beds for tourists. Testimonial to Dean Butoher. A meeting will be held at the Britwh Agency at 4. p.m. on Wednesday, 28th inst., in order to consider the question of presenting a tr-sti monial to the V*ry Rev. Dean Batcher. D D., before his departure Irom Egypt. Tin Earl oi Cromer tnd the Hon. L M. hidings will preside. All friends of DeaD Butcher (ladies as woll as gentlemen) are invited to attend. Alexandria Pier. 'fhe scheme for tin pior on the Alex andria quay is practically settled. The final arrangements will be decided on at the forthcoming meeting of the Alexandria Municipal Commission. This will be a great boon to the Alexandria public, and should prove, if well managed, a successful venture. A handsome casino and restaurant are to In eree'ei on the pier. Motor Boats for Egypt. Captain E.T. D xon, late R A., and Captain R.T. Dixon, late RE., the senior partners in tho weli known motor-boat firm cf Dixon Brothers and Hutchinson, of Southampton, ha\e brought u fle-t of pe'rol motor boats to Alexandria wi’h a‘view to pushing this important r.ew i idustiy in Egypt. They have already sold a line s'a going boat of this description to Mr. Gr-o. B. A lifers'n for nse at his seaside residence in Abonkir Bay. He bus consented y-not. to take delivery for another month, during which time that boat, with the rest of the fleet. will pay a visit to Cairo bv way of ha Malhnondieh Canal and the Nile At Cairo, the motor boats will be exhibited in the river for the benefit of intending purchases. The craft are all about thirty feet in length and embrace three separate classes, the river ex rese, the and vessels for ferry purposes and transport. The express brats have taken several prizes and are well known on the Sotent, where they have been racing last before.

div.head: Morocco
div.p: Demonstration in Force Imminent
MADRID, November 21. The authorities are preparing to land 500 marines in Morocco. It is believed here that a demonstration in force with the agreement of France and Great Britain is imminent. (R.)
Royal Visit to Berlin
Kaiser's Faithful Friend

BERLIN. November 19. The King of Denmark arrived here thin morning. He was warmly welcomed by the authorities and the population. The King declared to the burgomaster of the city that he had come as a faithful friend of the Emperor, whom he greatly esteemed. The King with accompanied by the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Connt Riben-Levetzm. (R.) BERLIN, November 19. The King and Queen of Norway will visit the Imperial Court about the middle of December. (Reuter)
Kaiser Justifies Himself
Working for Germany's Future

WORKING FOR GERM ANY’S FUTURE. BERLIN, November 20. The Emperor has authorized the publication of an interview he had with the Bavarian poet Qanghnfer, in which he declared himself an optimist who is working h*rd for Germany’s future. He would like people to understand him and help him attain the objects he has in view. It is believed that the publication of the interview is a reply to the recent speech in the Press. f (Reuter)
French Policy.
An Anglo-French Military Convention

PARIS, November 21. CHAMBER OK DEPUTIES —M. Clemenoean, replying to a question, said that he had not been sufficiently long in office to spy whether an Anglo French military convention executed, but he did not think so. The church inventories which are being carried out in France are fiercely opposed, especially in Britain y where brickbats and burning Sulphur are employed to resist the troop. (Reuter) PARIS, November SO. After a speech by M C emencean, justifying the home and foreign policy, and especially the inventories, the Senate passed a vote of confidence in the Ministry by 213 votes against 32. (llcnat)
The Government
An Appeal to the Country

LONDON, November 20. The Liberal papers are confident that the Government will not resign on the Education Bill, aud declare that they intend to force all their measures through the Commons and then appeal to the country with a complete case. {Reuter)
Transvaal Letters-Patent
Practically Complete
LONDON. November 20. It is understood 'hat the Transvaal Letters Patent are practically complete, and will receive the Royal approval before the end of the month. (heuter)
Army Billeting
Novel Scheme
LONDON. November 20. The First Aldershot Division has carried on, in the neighborhood of Camberley, a novel scheme of billeting on the German style. 5,000 men were billeted in two hours. (Reuter)
The New Duma
Socialism Preponderant
ST PETERSBURG, November 20. Notwithstanding the G vernment attempt to stifle voting it is expected that the Socialist element will preponderate in the new Duma. (Reuter)
Suffragette In Prison
LONDON, November 20. The suffragette who was arrested was fined 1OS. or to receive seven days imprisonment. She decided to go to prison. Mrs. Daspard gave evidence claiming the ring leadership. (R.
Another Springbok Victory
LONDON, November 20. Football. Rugby. The Smith Africans beat the North of Scotland by 35 points to 3. (Reuter)

div.head: Alexandria Municipality.
div.p: Budgetary Estimates for 1907

According to the report of the Administrator of the Alexandria Municipality on the budgetary estimates for 1907, the latter figure out as follows :— Revenue L.E. 221,000 Expenditure „ 217.3rO Reserve L.E. 3,700 The continual progress of the municipal sources of revenue, says Mr. Chataway,. allows him to foresee for 1907 receipts exceeding by L.E. 26.000 those embodied in the Budget of 1906 This satisfactory augmentation is mainly due to increased revenue under the head of the tax on buildings (LE 7,80>), the tax on carriages and beasts of burden (L.E. 4,1' 0), the 2% house tax L.E. 2,500;, road dues (L.E. 3.2C0), quarry dues (LE 2,500), abattoir receipts (L E. 2,000;, etc. After referring in detail to the various heads of revenue the Administrator says that the fact matt not be lost sight of that the budgetary equilibrium is only last maintained by the Municipality’s present resources, and that if the budget has sensibly increased, it is far from having reached the amount whioh the needs and charges of the city will shortly necessitate for .the upkeep of all the new works which have already been undertaken, and which the flesh extraordinary resources will allow them to undertake in a more or less early future, for the sanitation, aeration, and embellishment of the town. Chataway Bey adds : — "The creation of a big reserve suggested by me in a previous report is logically dependent on the importance of the excels of receipts over expenditure ; it is then fore materially impossible, unless by a reduction of expenditure—to the detriment of the real needs of our various services—to establish a bigger reserve, so long as fresh resources do no arise to increase the present revenue of the ordinary Budget, the more so as the budgetary estimates of revenue reflect exactly all that we shall be able approximately to euros in 1907, and the amount of which it would be imprudent to raise.” As regards expenditure, the estimates are established in such a manner as to ensure the working of the services not only such as tiny had been provided for in 1906 but also according to the situation and with the extension which they have undergone since. The report says that, taking into consideration the obligatory or unforeseen expenditure which the Municipality has to meet with its ordinary resources, and the desire expressed by the Municipal Delegation concerning the inscription on the Budget of 1907 of a reserve more to keeping with the needs of the city, the amount of the grants made annually by the Municipality to the various benevolent societies and other institutions, and which conatitate optional expenditure (less the amount set aside for the free distribution of water to the poor), might be deducted from the ordinary Budget, to be included henceforth in the extraordinary Budget. Chataway Bey adds : "While folly recognizing the useful work done J)y these institutions, I consider it more regular and more in conformity with the regulations and the interests of the administration itself not to take out of the ordinary Budget funds which might be devoted to maintenance and the obligatory expenditure of the city. Io this way the reserve of the ordinary Budget will be brought up to LE. 9,231.”
Delegation Municpals

La D4HgAtion Municipals s’est rlanie le 20 Novembre 1906 k 5 h. p.m. sous la prodeuce de S.E. le Dr. Schiess Pacha. Presents: MM. Ahmed Pacha Yehia, E. Benachi, Soliman Bey Abani, Mansoor Bey Youfsef, Dr. G. Valensin, G. Zervudachi, mem- bres; w. P. Chataway, administrateor; I. Sadky Bey, secretaire. La Delegation emet on echange d’idees an sujet des propositions relatives k la creation di noovelles resources, question qai a fait Fob-jet d’on examen de la part do Comite des Finances. Cette question sera soomise k la Commission Municipals aveo les observations generates emise* par la Delegation k son sujet. La Delegation eit favorable en prinoipe k la proposition, adoptee par le Comite des Finances, tendant k la location de certains terrains stir les qnais, et decide do la soumettre k la Commission Munioipale. Elle reuvoie au Comite des Travaux Publics uu projet de lotissement des oollines de Hadra, au Nord de la route d’Aboakir. La Delegation autorise la construction d’une canalisation dans la rue Sidi Wakie. aveo la contribution de* proprietaires riverains. Bile renvo;e au Comite special deux demanded de msjoration d’allocations de la ligae oontre la tuberculose et de 1’Association des seconr* d’urgenco. La Delegation fixe la prochaine *e*nce de la Commission an meroredi 20 novembre 1906 et en arrgte l’ordre do jonr. Elle F6 rdunira saroedi prochain pour l’exa- men des propositions bndgetaires presentees par l’adaiinistrateur. I,a France eat levle k 8 b. p.m.

div.head: United Egyptian Lands.
Important Flotation
div.p: This company has been formed with a capital of £500,000, divided into 498.750 Ordinary shares of £| each, and 25.000 Deferred shares of 1s each.. The Ordinary shares are entitled to a preferential dividend of 7 per cent and will participate with the Deferred shares in the remaining profit available for distribution, the Ordinary share taking sixty per cent., and the Deferred shares the remaining forty per cent. There will be an issue of 298.750 Ordinary shares, payable as follow* :—2s. 6d per share on application; 2s. 6d. per share on allotment; and the balance in calls not exceeding 5s. per share, at intervals or not less than three months. The subscription list will be opened on the 10th December, 1906, and closed on or before the 1th December 1906. One-third of the whole issue will be reserved for Egypt. The directors are Major-General Sir John C. Ardagh, K C.M.G.. K C.I.E, C.B., repre sentative of H.B.M.'s Government on the Board of Administration of the Suez Canal Company; Mr. Elias Meyer, of Meyer Bros , Calcutta. and R Meyer & Co., Singapore; and Mr. Gerald Arthur 8beppard, deputy-chairman of Egyptian Estates, Limited. The advisory board in Egypt consists of Mr. John Hicks Pauli and Neghib J. Sarsock Bey. The Egypt secretary will be Mr. Errol Kerr, C. A., of Messrs.Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, Alexandria and Cairo. The company has been formed especially to carry on business in Egypt and the Sudan. The attention of the Board will, as opportunities present themselves, be more particularly directed .to: The purchase, development and subsequent leasing or re-sale of agricultural and building land ; the lending of money, on mortgage or otherwise, on land or other approved securities ; the carrying on of the business of an investment company. The company will mainly devote itself to the development of selected agricultural estates with a view to their rental or sale to natives in plots suitable to their requirements. The directors consider themselves fortunate in having secured the services of Mr. John Hicks Paoll, as agricultural adviser for a period of three years. Excellent opportunities frequently occur of leading money on first mortgage at good rates and with an ample margin. With a local advisory board composed of business men ot high standing and long experience in Egypt good profits may reasonably be expected from this and other forms of investment which require special local knowledge. The company has acquired from the H. and J. Syndicate, Limited, the right to purchase an estate of 4,793 feddans (say 5 000 English acres), situated some miles south of Alexandria and connected by a line of tramway with the Delta Light Railways system. The estate is a going concern, with ample farm buildings, stock, plant, etc. It his excellent soil and an ample water supply. Mr. Lang Anderson reports that it is "a! property capable of great development at! moderate cost and that if £30,000 be judiciously spent on it during the next five years it can be brought to a capital value of from . £75 to £80 per feddan.” He farther adds that "the work of development is simple and follows well-known lines, so that the element I of unforeseen contingencies iB largely diminish- I ed, while the results of development are sure.” The present rental value of the estate is nearly £1,000 per annum, derived from an area of under 1,000 feddans let to natives, and Mr. Anderson sees no reason why, when folly developed, the estate should not yield an annual revenue of at least £21,500, whilst its capital value may reasonably be expected to improve by from 70 to 80 per cent The directors have other business in view which is believed to be a most profitable nature ; as, however, negotiations are still in progress, it is not possible to give details at present. All the agricultural properties already acquired as well as those in contemplation have been treated with after personal examination by Mr. LaDg Anderson.
The Khedive

The Khedive left for Marioat yesterday morning and returned to Montazih in the evening. There will be a reception on the platform of the Moharrem Bey terminus at 7.30 a.m. on the 24th inst. on the occasion of the Khedive’s departure from Alexandria for Cairo. A guard of honor of 100 rank and file, commanded by a captain, with two subalterns, the King’s colour and band to the 1st Battalion Linooshire Fusiliers, will mount at Cairo railway station at 11.15 a.m. on Saturday next, on the occasion of the arrival of the Khedive. The Khedive will bold his first reception on his return to Cairo for the winter en Monday morning next. His Highness dispatched the usual congratulatory telegram to the Sultan on the occasion to Beyram.
Sudden Death of Cadi

Wo regret to announce the death of Sheikh Ahmed Abou Kbalwa, Cadi of the Supreme Mehkemeh Sbareh, who died in Cairo yester. day. He was a renowned Arabic scholar and man of letters. The Sheikh died very suddenly, being taken ill yesterday morning while going to his office.

div.head: Jane Hading in Cairo
"La Princessa Georges"
(From our Theatrical Correspondent)
div.p: Jane Hading was all and more than we had hoped to see and hear. She had a perfection of gesture, voice, intonation.—all that the French school has at its highest. In the play given, "La Princesse George” she somehow gave the personality and note of the piece, and yet her own self was at its strength: it was, in fact, the Princess played by Jane Hading, and not Jane Hading alor.e. submerging all the play. The piece is not profoundly interesting in itself, except for one or two moments of excitement, and of course the revolver incident at the end; it has the touch of discorsiveness and sentimental philosophy ore find* in Domas fils.. This was marked with the other actor*. They are excellent of their kind and play well np to Jane Hading herself; bat the piece, the traditions of—well—elocution, and even the theatre in which they were playing bad their effect. The "asides,” for instance, were almost shouted. But the Abbas Theatre is not good for acting, and the voice does not carry well. Jane Hading has to impersonate a woman deceived, and forgiving, again deceived, then resolute, but conquered by her love after all, and then happy in that she has driven out her rival and sent that rival’s lover to face the pistol of an infuriated husband ; the prince returns unhurt, and after all not the archdeceiver she feared. Her impersonations was as great as can be imagined. That touch we have spoken of discursive and sentimental, did not appear : every word, every movement, was natural; now passionate, now proud, pleading, forgiving, jealous, condemning, she held the whole theatre. Her influence caught one by the throat, as it were. And what a voice ! We have heard the ultra- correct Theatre d’Orange declamaton. the Opera Ccm que elocution, the exaggeration- shriek for certain crises, Mme Granier, the woman of the world. None were quite so perfect and true. Yet we did notice once or twice—always when she was alone on the stage, never when playing with one of the others Just a touch of forced note. At one moment there was a suspicion of deep tone as of Sarah, and now and again the voice rose high, and the ge9tare seemed excessive. That may have been the seven days at Alexandria, or the audience of Monday night; one expects it in the Khedivial Theatre ! But her great effect, the tease, harried, passionate whisper, and then at the last that strangled shriek of despair ! How can actresses rant and boom and howl when such wonders can be done by other means ! And again the “voix terne” lifeless and light less when her love gave way before damning proofs : it was all a wonder. We have spoken of the others. The prince was good enough, ai was Galanson, MM. Amaod and Grammont ; and Victor gave the right note of the perfect valet waiting to make money, and repenting a moment ; but his asides j irred greatly. Ha need not have compromised with the theatre acoustics to such an extent. Sylvanie de Terremoode (Laure Sarean) was too theatrical. She might have been Winifred Emery playing a character of 3etoo Merriman’s, and over accentuating her points. The other ladies were all a little traditional ; and their pronunciation was almost too corrupt. This is not to say that they were not one and all far better than, say, the average Khedivial troupe. The house was not very fall, bat it is a big theatre, and then unless one is well in front it is very difficult to hear properly. The management might perhaps give a little more notice when the curtain is going to rise. We are sure they will ; they are always most courteous and careful. But on Monday night at the beginning of each set there was a certain amount of disturbance. People only just found out that the curtain was op. and had to get to their places while the play was going on.
Jerusalem Consulate.
Appointment of New Cousul

Jerusalem, November 17. Mr. Edward Charles Blech, who since 1894 has held the post of dragoman archivist to the British Embassy at Constantinople, has recently been appointed his Majesty’s Consul for Palestine, to reside at Jerusalem. He arrived here this morning, but will not enter upon hi official duties until next May, having obtained leave of absence. He intends to return to Constantinople after a couple of days to join his family homeward. Mr. F. G. Freeman, his Msjssty’s Consol at Trebizond, will oontinue to take obarge of the Consulate until Mr. Blech’s return. The nomination of Mr. Bleoh, who is still a young man, is hailed with much satisfaction here. His ability and thorough knowledge of the Arabio and Turkish languages, coupled with the vast experience he has acquired of Turkish affairs during a long residence in the Capital and in other parts of the Ottoman Empire, would seem to well qualify him to fill the post for which be has been selected.
Steamer Movements

The Moss liner Seti arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool via Gibraltar and Malts, with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The Ellerman liner City of Venice arrived at Liverpool from Alexandria list Tuesday morning. The S.S. Egyptian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on 'he 20th ii-at, and is due at Alexandria on Saturday morning

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: The Ox-Empress Bagenie intends to spend part of this season in Egypt.
Mastapha Pasha Fehmy, the Premier, is on a tour of inspection which is to inolode Man- Bonrah and Damietta. He will retorn to Alexandria in order to accompany the Khedive
to Cairo.
Gh«zi Mokhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, will leave Alexandria for Cairo on Moaday next

Marquis di Soragno, Italian Consul-General in Cairo, oame dowa to Alexandria yeitarday to take up the post of Consul-General left vanant by Baron Acton, who is leaving for his new post at Galatz, Ron mania, by tbs Roumanian steamer to-morrow.
The Counsellors of the Native Coart if Appeal yesterday gave a banquet at the Grand Continental Hotel to Soad Pa«ba Zaghloul on the occasion of his new appointment.

A banquet was given at Mena House on Monday by the departmental chiefs and staff of the Ministry of Justice in honor of 0aman Bey Mortada on the occasion of his appointment ag Counsellor at the Mixed Tribalal of Alexandria.
Ahmed Bey Zulfikar, judge of the Mixed Court of Mausourab, has refused the offer of the post of moudir, made to him by Mr. Machell.
Mr. D. P. MacGillivray, Governor of the Bar k of Abyssinia, has arrived in Cairo and is at present staying at 8hepheard’s Hotel.
Lieut.-Col. Sir Richards Carnao Temple, chairman of the Egyptian Engineering, Commercial and Industrial Company, has arrived in Egypt, and is staying at Shepheard’s Hotel.
Mr. Louis Belrose, of Washington, who has been appointed to a position in the America] Consul General’s office at Cairo, is now on his way to Egypt.

Among the passengers by the S.S. Osmania which arrived on Sunday from Constantinople were Mr. Pearoe, Mr. and Mme Q. Imbanlt, Mr. and Mr*. W. R*es, Miss Holland, Mr. Holland, Mr. Hirscb, Fonad Bey, Mr. Kelley, Mr. John H. Milan, Mr. H. E. Jones. Mr. W. S. George, Miss Williamson.

div.head: Pith of the Press
Extracts From Home Papers
div.p: Internal Discontent In Germany.

On the eve of the meeting of the Reishstag General von Podbiflski’s resignation has been accepted. The Prussian Minister of Agriculture leaves office adorned with the insignia of one of the most illustrious Orders which his Sove reign has to bestow. His retirement will nevertheless be generally regarded as a recognition of the force and authority of public opinion. The late Minister was unpopular with the masses of the German people because of the extreme views upon agricultural protection which he shared with the narrowest and the most conservative of the Prussian Agrarians. His policy has left its mark upon the new treaties of commerce which Germany has been concluding with her neighbors, and at home it is regarded as one of the main causes of the great rise in the cost of meat which is occasioning such widespread discontent in the

The sacrifice is, no doubt, expedient, bat it will hardly suffice to assuage the general discontent and. uneasiness-t which are said to pervade almost all classes of the German nation. These feelings have their root in causes far wider and deeper than resentment at the conduct of an individual Minister, or even than displeasure at the general conduct of public affairs. They arise not from the mismanagement of those affairs, though with a nation which has its full share of vanity this doubt- leas has helped to influence them, but from the great and growing dissatisfaction that the management of the country should remain exclusively confined to the present, hands. An influential South German newspaper boldly attributes them to what it calls, with some petulance perhaps, a “crisis of absolutism.” The phrase is exaggerated, but that it expresses a truth no observers who have watched the growth of modern Germany, and the dove lopment of political thought within her borders, will question. ("TiroFs”).
A Plea for Official Recognition.

Sensitive as they are to fluctuations in international prestige, the subjects of William II. are, at present, more nearly concerned with the prolonged negation of their civic rights. They cast their eyes abroad, and see that the peoples of less intellectual and less progressive countries have a definite voice in the management of their domestic affairs. A Frenchman, an Italian, V1 Austrian, or -Hungarian, even a Bulgarian or Servian, can take his part in the making or unmaking of a Ministry. In Germany, if there is a "Chancellor crisis, ’ the electors are but an audience invited to witness a show which is planned and managed behind

The situation would, perhaps, be considered less intolerable if the only parties concerned were Emperor and Reichstag, King and people. Bat between the Monarch and his subjects stands the Court camarilla, a clique of flatterers and adventurers, whose business it is to prevent the Ruler from ascertaining the mind and thought of the nation. If we may believe the journals—which are, without distinction of party, practically unanimous—the courtiers are only too successful in the arts of mystification. They play alike cn the finer impulses of the Emperor’s character and on the lees noble traits—on his generosity, his self reliance, and his vanity. Nihil estquod credere de se Nod possit cum laudatur dis a qua potestas. It is hard, indeed, for an absolute Ruler to ignore adulation and set a limit to his own capacity. ( ‘Standard.”)
Belgium and the Congo.

In the course of his speech at the Guildhall banquet on Friday last, the Marquees of Ripon pointed out that the be3t solution of the Congo difficulty lay in the annexation by Belgium of the territories of the Free State, which thenceforward would exist only as a Belgian colony. In that event it may be assumed that Belgium’s national pride could not for a moment allow her to countenance the perpetuation of the system with which the rule of her Sovereign in Africa is unhappily associated, if she should decide to take this step and to assume the burden which would thereby be cast upon her, she may be well assured that she will be hampered by no interference on the part of this country. Rather than that she may rely on the energetic sympathy of all persons who have recognized that in this course lies the salvation of the Congo natives. If, however, Belgium should not see her way to undertake this duty, then, as Lord Ripon pointed out on Friday, it will be for this country and the other Powers to consider what concerted action may be taken to enforce the provisions of the Berlin Act of 1885 (“Morning Post.”)
